message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only hypothyroidism is known to cause abnormal prolactin production, which can lead to nipple discharge. The patient’s high TSH level also suggests hypothyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypothyroidism can cause the nipple discharge due to increased prolactin secretion. The elevated TSH suggests hypothyroidism, and the other options do not fit with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently not taking levothyroxine. High levels of prolactin, which can cause nipple discharge, can be caused by hypothyroidism. Thyrotropic pituitary adenoma (A) would cause elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone and enlarged pituitary, which are not present in this patient. Ectopic prolactin production (B) and Cushing disease (C) are less likely given the patient's symptoms and lab values.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which can lead to hyperprolactinemia and nipple discharge. The elevated TSH further supports the diagnosis of hypothyroidism. While prolactinoma can cause nipple discharge, the patient has no evidence of pituitary adenoma on imaging studies. Ectopic prolactin production and Cushing disease are less likely and not supported by other laboratory findings or clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypothyroidism can cause an increase in prolactin secretion, which can lead to nipple discharge. The other options are less likely based on the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypothyroidism, which can cause elevated prolactin levels and lead to nipple discharge. None of the other options are associated with nipple discharge.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypothyroidism, which may cause nipple discharge due to hyperprolactinemia. Elevated prolactin is also seen in Thyrotropic pituitary adenoma and Ectopic prolactin production, but these options are less likely as the patient’s prolactin levels are not significantly elevated. Cushing disease is not related to nipple discharge or hyperprolactinemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of irregular menstrual cycles, vaginal atrophy, fatigue, and weight gain suggest hypothyroidism, which is also supported by the high TSH level. The nipple discharge and high prolactin level can be explained by the effect of hypothyroidism on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of prolactin. Therefore, the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient is hypothyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory test results suggest hypothyroidism, which can cause galactorrhea (nipple discharge) due to increased prolactin levels. Thyrotropic pituitary adenoma and Cushing disease have different symptoms and laboratory findings, while ectopic prolactin production is rare.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypothyroidism and not taking levothyroxine, which can cause hyperprolactinemia and nipple discharge. None of the other options are related to hypothyroidism or hyperprolactinemia.
